citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two birds from two walk-in aviaries are unaccounted for since the last inspection of 10 February 2025, which include 1
Broad-billed hummingbird and 1 Swainson's thrush. A keeper record dated 28 February 2025 notes that the Swainson's
thrush is missing and presumed dead. The last recorded keeper note for the Broad-billed hummingbird dated 29 February
2025 states that the bird was unable to be found. A facility representative does not know the last observance of the birds
and the birds have not been recovered. One aviary houses hummingbirds only and the other is a mixed species exhibit
housing approximately 90 birds. Both aviaries are outdoor enclosures with double door entries.
Failure to conduct daily observations of birds does not allow for accountability of birds in the collection, potential changes
in health status or injury, which may lead to death. Daily observation of all animals must be performed to assess their
health and well-being. There shall be a mechanism of direct and frequent communication on problems of animal health,
behavior and well-being to the attending veterinarian.

On April 1st, 2025, the facility self-reported that a female Harris's Hawk “Dot” flew off on March 27, 2025, while performing
in the free flight raptor exhibition. The Harris’s Hawk equipped with a telemetry unit, diverted from her typical flight path for
the exhibition into a soaring pattern with a wild Harris's Hawk. While performing their standard operating procedures for
flyoff recovery efforts the facility recovered the tail feather and attached telemetry unit. She has not been observed in the
area since the day of disappearance, and she has not been recovered. Failure to recapture the animal may result in harm
or death to the animal. During the public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the
animal and so as to assure the safety of the animal.
Correct from this date forward of 12 May 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Critical Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Two birds from two walk-in aviaries are unaccounted for since the last inspection of 10 February 2025, which include 1 
Broad-billed hummingbird and 1 Swainson's thrush. A keeper record dated 28 February 2025 notes that the Swainson's 
thrush is missing and presumed dead. The last recorded keeper note for the Broad-billed hummingbird dated 29 February 
2025 states that the bird was unable to be found. A facility representative does not know the last observance of the birds 
and the birds have not been recovered. One aviary houses hummingbirds only and the other is a mixed species exhibit 
housing approximately 90 birds. Both aviaries are outdoor enclosures with double door entries. 
 
Failure to conduct daily observations of birds does not allow for accountability of birds in the collection, potential changes 
in health status or injury, which may lead to death. Daily observation of all animals must be performed to assess their 
health and well-being. There shall be a mechanism of direct and frequent communication on problems of animal health, 
behavior and well-being to the attending veterinarian. 
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On April 1st, 2025, the facility self-reported that a female Harris's Hawk “Dot” flew off on March 27, 2025, while performing 
in the free flight raptor exhibition. The Harris’s Hawk equipped with a telemetry unit, diverted from her typical flight path for 
the exhibition into a soaring pattern with a wild Harris's Hawk. While performing their standard operating procedures for 
flyoff recovery efforts the facility recovered the tail feather and attached telemetry unit. She has not been observed in the 
area since the day of disappearance, and she has not been recovered. Failure to recapture the animal may result in harm 
or death to the animal. During the public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the 
animal and so as to assure the safety of the animal.  
 
Correct from this date forward of 12 May 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.

Additional Inspectors: 
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
